posts.cooked: hii we creating our on elivetor and we need to conecte the elivator chine to the elivator and i want to know what is the best way to do that can u write how u do that or how u recomned to do that

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
The best way is to use a chain break tool to attach an in-line chain tensioner .

7 links to 4 suppliers in one post, is that a record?

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked: Depending on the size of the chain, there are attachment links that can fasten chain to surrounding structure.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Ahh, I clearly read the question differently :). Here’s another example . And another .

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
image 862×607 100 KB Wcp has a pretty nice design, it doesn’t require special chain links. unfortunately, Wcp doesn’t sell these parts alone for some reason . Depending on the level of Manfacturing you have access to these could be made custom.

image 862×607 100 KB

image 862×607 100 KB

Edit: Just look at the next post

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Thriftybot sells this “chain comb” style:

This part is custom designed to interface 25 and 25H chain to various robot parts. Includes three 10-32 threaded holes in the base of the part and three M3 threaded studs. Stud posts are designed to fit perfectly in-between chain links. Material is...

Price: USD 22.99

Peyton already posted the andymark version that would be a good for for frc:

These connecting chain attachment links, also known as K-links, are perfect for securing components that need movement to a chain. These versions were specifically designed by AndyMark to interface with common FRC and FTC products. The #35 chain...

Here are the more generic Mcmaster carr ones of the andymark product:

McMaster-Carr is the complete source for your plant with over 595,000 products. 98% of products ordered ship from stock and deliver same or next day.
